column1: description

Though he'd rather be a musical genius, Jean-François Reaud did wonders with this estate, in the family since 1904. Dense and full of tannins, it also offers ripe fruits. Its structure and density match the intensity of the fruit, meaning the wine has a great future. With a dense aftertaste, the wine will age, so drink from 2022.

Mint aromas signal the wood aging of this ripe wine. It is named after François Carreau, credited with being the first in Bordeaux to graft rootstock onto vines to protect against phylloxera. The wine is full, poised between big tannins and equally important dark fruits. This impressive wine will age well, but will not be ready before 2022.

The fifth-generation Filliatreaus are working the estate's Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon well. Bold tannins are balanced by rich blackberry flavors in this wine. The combination gives it a fine future, rich, concentrated and dense. Acidity at the end adds the necessary lift. Drink from 2022.

The Carreau cousins, Nicolas and Sébastien, continue to make waves with this 2015 acquisition of the chateau. This balanced and structured wine spent six months in old oak barrels. Its blackberry fruits are ably assisted by the generous tannins and dry core. This rich wine will age well, ready to drink from 2022.

While this wine shows lots of wood flavors at this stage, it will soften. The wine also has ripe berry fruits, rich tannins and good acidity. Once these integrate, this will be a rich wine. Drink from 2020.

Ripe, dense and perfumed, this wine offers rich blackberry fruits and generous tannins. It is a structured wine, firm but with swathes of fruit. The estate has been owned by the Carreau family since 1832. Drink from 2021.

While this wine has plenty of tannins, solid, dark fruits shine through the structure. Consultant Stéphane Derenoncourt has created a powerful wine, with juicy black-currant fruits and a ripe, solid aftertaste. Drink from 2022.

This firm and structured Merlot-based wine conveys a light touch of wood from older barrels. It is rich with tannins and fruit. The dry core surrounded by ripe blackberry fruits promises a rich future. Drink this well-structured wine from 2022.
This bold, ripe wine is full of delicious black fruits. It has plenty of tannins as well, but it is the fruit that shines, ripe, generous and with good acidity. Drink this wine from 2022.

This dark, structured wine with firm tannins has the potential for richness. That comes from the blackberry flavors that are coming through the dry structure. The fruit hints at juiciness as well as acidity. Drink this ageworthy wine from 2022.

Dense with tannins, this wine has power and concentration. The tannins are generously paired with rich fruits and acidity. These elements all point to a wine that needs time to mature and release its full power. Drink from 2022.

This is a densely textured wine, packed with dark tannins as well as black fruits. It is concentrated, boasting the structure of the vintage. Blackberries vie with the firm structure, with both suggesting plenty of potential. Drink this Carreau wine from 2022.

Big, bold fruits and tannins are already coming into balance in this concentrated wine. It revels in the richness of the vintage and also its structure. Acidity breaks through the tannins and berry fruits to add freshness at the end. Drink from 2021.

Balanced and structured, this rich organic wine is generous and packed with black fruits. Concentration and layers of wood are all part of Jean-François Reaud's fruity wine that will age well. Drink from 2021.

A ripe, full and juicy wine, this is rich with tannins as well as black-currant flavors. Power and concentration are balanced by the fruitiness. Acidity and hints of wood aging add final complexity. Drink from 2021.

Ripe and balanced, this rich, structured, mostly Merlot wine offers fine tannins and layers of berry fruits. Concentrated and dense, the wine will develop well, with plenty of fruitiness as well as a firm structure. Drink this Vignobles Bayle Carreau wine from 2022.
Richly balanced, this ripe, black-fruit -lavored wine has a good future. Its dark texture and generous tannins promise much, backed up by fresher acidity. Drink this Carreau wine from 2022.

This rich, generous wine from a small vineyard has great black fruits as well as ripe tannins. While young, it has power and density to enhance the warm berry flavors. These will bulk up further to give a powerful wine. Drink from 2022.

This wine has ripe black fruits to go with its rich tannins. Planted to 90% Merlot and 10% Cabernet Sauvignon, the 22-acre vineyard has produced a wine with solid textures and juicy acidity that point up the weight of the fruit. Drink this generous, spicy wine from 2022.

This wine from fifth-generation vigneron Jean-Michel Baudet is full of perfumed new wood and also plenty of ripe, black fruits, suggesting excellent potential. With structure and rich fruits, it is going to develop into a complex wine. Drink from 2022.

This wine from Jean-François Baudet is rich with fine tannins and ripe black fruits. Its structure and concentration are generous, while with 12 months in oak, the smoky black-currant fruit still gives freshness. The wine is now well integrated and will be ready from 2021.

This ripe wine offers new-wood mint and spice flavors as well as rich tannins. They are balanced by generous blackberry fruits and juicy acidity to give a full-bodied wine that will age well over the medium term. Drink from 2021.

Named after the owner's father, this richly structured wine has both berry fruits and ripe tannins. Firm where it needs to be, it is also generous in its blackberry flavors and acidity. The wine delivers a juicy aftertaste. Drink from 2021.

Minty aromas suggest new wood and plenty of spice. The wood aging has given the wine a strongly toasty character that dominates the fruit. Allow time for the black-currant flavors to come through and balance the burnt toastiness. Drink from 2022 when it will be a balanced wine.

Wood aromas from aging for 12 months in barrels dominate this wine and the wood shows strongly on the palate. However, the berry flavors and acidity are also well placed to integrate with the wood and tannic structure. so the wine should age well. Drink this Vignobles Bayle Carreau wine from 2022.

With 90% Merlot, this Denis Lafon wine is ripe and jammy. It has a good structure, showing the wood aging strongly. Touches of licorice contrast with the big black-fruit flavors and dense texture. Drink the wine from 2020.

This Jean-François Reaud property offers a Merlot-dominant juicy, ripe wine that's packed with black-currant flavors. Acidity and firm tannins back up the fruitiness to give a wine with plenty of freshness and a crisp aftertaste. Drink from 2021.

Firm tannins don't mask the berry fruits and acidity in this wine. It has a juicy, forward character backed by tannins.Touches of wood aging from the 12 months in barrel give a dry core. Drink from 2021.

The Dartier sister-and-brother team created a wine of rich fruit and minty aromas balanced by new wood and black fruit flavors. Harvested late in the season, as was typical for the vintage, it's a ripe wine that's fruity and juicy, yet structured and firm. Drink from 2022.

The heavy bottle tells you this is meant to be a statement wine. It comes from the vineyard's best parcels, which have produced a richly endowed wine, dark and concentrated, powered by the tannins. It needs to age and will not be ready before 2022.
Soft and fruity, this mainly Merlot wine is approachable already. Black-currant flavors and generous tannins work well together to give a juicy wine, full of acidity. Drink from 2021.

Ripe, smoky and filled with black fruits, this wine has all the elements for aging. Not for the long-term, but over the next few years, its tannins will develop to support to the full berry flavors. Drink from 2021.

This richly fruity wine offers great tannins and layers of black-currant and berry flavors from the Merlot/Cabernet Sauvignon/Cabernet Franc blend. With no apparent wood flavors, the freshness of the fruit is palpable, partnered by the supporting tannins behind. Drink the wine from 2020.

This is an immediately attractive, ready-to-drink wine. Its soft tannins and bright fruit are already open. With berry flavors, ripe acidity and a generous, rich aftertaste, it is balanced, with great fruitiness at the end.

Now fully mature, this attractively perfumed wine is full of jammy berry fruits, mint and spice from wood aging. The wine is a blend of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, full in the mouth without being heavy. It is delicious to drink now.
This richly perfumed wine is ripe with both tannins and concentrated blackberry fruits. From a 24-acre estate, it has weight, density and a good future. Drink this structured, juicy wine from 2021.
Vignobles Ardoin's Merlot-dominated wine is well structured and full of fruits. The tannins and blackberry flavors are full bodied and integrated, giving richness and a fine future. Drink from 2021.
Ripe, rich and juicy, this is a full, warm and rounded wine. Fine tannins are layered with plenty of acidity and berry flavors. Spice comes through to fill out this ripe wine. Drink from 2021.

Structured and firm, this wine has weight and dense tannins. Black- coffee flavors hint at extraction although the ripe berry fruits act as a balance and contrast. This wine will take a while to develop, so wait until 2022.

This dense Denis Lafon wine is packed with tannins and also with juicy, ripe Merlot fruit, offering the potential for aging. Black-currant flavors are laced through the firm structure and the serious tannins. It has a good future after 12 months in wood, some of it new. The wine's structure is still firm and the wine will gradually open out. Drink from 2020.
Aged in tank, this ripe, fruity wine is packed with red-berry flavors. Ripe tannins support the fruitiness and acidity. It's an attractive wine that will develop relatively quickly. Drink from 2020.

Jean-Michel Bergeron's wine is developing well, showing ripe fruits, wood flavors and some tannins. It offers red-berry flavors, spice and a core of dryness that will allow it to age further. Drink this wine from Vignobles Gabriel from 2021.

A ripe and spicy wine, this has warm tannins and juicy acidity. Its soft structure allows the red-berry flavors to speak strongly. As it develops this fruitiness will become even more pronounced. Drink from 2021.

This firmly structured, limited-production wine also has plenty of ripe, black fruits. Bold tannins and dark-chocolate flavors are balanced by black plum fruits that are developing underneath. Drink from 2022.
Bold, ripe and rich, this is a concentrated wine. Its dark tannins have a smoky edge from the wood aging. It needs time. Drink from 2021.
Fresh, fruity and with crisp acidity, this wine is already approachable. It is bright with black-currant flavors that lift tannins that are giving a dry core. Drink from 2021.
Black fruits give this wine a good shape and richness. Backed by dark licorice and coffee flavors from 12 months in new French oak, the wine offers both structure and ripe spice. Drink from 2022.
Blackberry fruits dominate this ripe, lightly structured wine. Fine tannins contribute their rich texture. Drink from 2021.
Ripe red-berry flavors and gentle tannins set up a warm, rich wine dominated by Merlot. It has generous fruitiness, cut with acidity and a perfumed aftertaste. Drink from 2020.

This wine shows plenty of wood, with the 30% Malbec aged in French oak and the 70% Merlot in vat. The wine also has attractive dark fruits. Balance is coming as the smoky character of the wine softens to give generous tannins and bold black late-harvest fruits. Drink from 2022.

Hints of blackberry fruits and good acidity suggest this wine has potential. The tannins are very present at this stage but are balanced by the acidity and the fruits that are developing. Drink from 2022.
Ripe strawberry flavors come through strongly in this wine. Its berry fruits, generous sweetness and balanced acidity are all in place to offer a full-bodied, fruity wine from 2021.

An attractive, fruity wine with good acidity and firm tannins, this bottling is designed to be drunk soon. Juicy black-currant flavors are right up front, supported by ripe tannins. Drink this wine from 2020.

This dense Merlot/Cabernet Sauvignon blend offers ripe black fruits, rich tannins and good concentration. Aged for 18 months, the blackberry flavors are generous, backed by acidity and a smoky aftertaste. Drink from 2021.

Produced by Vignobles Carreau, this is a delicious, ripe and fruity wine. It also has layers of new wood and some firm tannins. The result is a balanced, generous wine powered by tannins but with generous swathes of black fruits. Drink from 2021.

Rich and dense, this is a concentrated wine dominated by 90% Merlot. New-wood flavors play around the black currants and ripe tannins. The structure and the ripeness promise good aging. Drink from 2022.

Black-currant fruits shine in this wine from an estate run by women for several generations. The fruits contrast with the firm tannic core. Freshness gives the wine a juicy, fruity character that will develop over the medium term. Drink from 2020.
This is a dry wine, with dark-hued tannins masking the potential of the ripe fruit. The licorice and black-coffee tastes suggest considerable extraction that needs time to soften. Wait until 2021.
Closed and firm at this young stage, this 95% Merlot wine has the potential for rich fruit and tannins. It shows weight and hints of the ripe flavors to come. Drink from 2022.

Produced by Jean-Michel Baudet, this polished wine is smooth with ripe tannins and rich berry fruits. It is concentrated and already balanced. The fruitiness suggests the wine will age quickly, so drink from 2021.
This is a smoky wine with licorice and red-fruit flavors. It is obviously still young, its ripe fruits showing alongside some firm tannins. Let it settle for a few months and drink from 2019.
Packed with tannins at this stage, this wine has a long-term future. The blackberry fruit weight is still developing and needs time. Wait until 2021.
This wine is soft, ripe and fruity, with good acidity and gentle tannins. Balanced and bright, it will develop quickly and should be ready to drink from 2021.

Firm tannins are the hallmark of this wine that has weight as well as ripe black fruits. Made with 91% Merlot and 9% Cabernet Franc, it has a dry core although the ample fruit will balance the wine as it ages. Drink from 2022.
This spicy wine shows a considerable amount of wood aging that has dried up the fruit. The richness might redeem it. Wait until 2022.
This fruity wine has attractive red berry flavors and soft tannins. It is ripe, with plenty of fresh acidity to brighten up the warm texture. Drink from 2019.
Strawberry fruits and sweet tannins are all of a piece in this jammy wine. The tannins are a soft hint in the background as this bottling develops into a wine for drinking early, certainly from 2020.
Firm and dry, this wine still has plenty of hints of the fruit to come. Juicy blackberry flavors are developing to balance the dense structure. It will be ready to drink from 2021.
A ripe and juicy wood-aged wine, this is rich in berry fruits as well as solid tannins. The balance of the wine is coming together well, offering the potential of generous structure. Drink from 2021.
Ripe berry fruits dominate this richly tannic wine. It has richness, concentration and a structure that will allow the wine to age. Drink from 2022.

Stored for six months in tanks, this wine is fruity and juicy, with soft tannins. Already attractive and developing well, it has weight and boasts the ripeness of the vintage, delivering a juicy aftertaste. Drink this wine from 2021.
This wine is all about dryness, with hard-edged fruit and firm tannins.
This wine is tight with tannins and a dry core. By contrast, the rest seems light and thin.
Jammy strawberry flavors mark this ripe wine. The fruit is perhaps too mature, giving an unbalanced aftertaste.
The fruit seems too ripe in this wine, giving a jammy character surrounding a dry core. It could balance better in a few years.
Jammy ripe fruit has become entangled with extracted tannins in this clumsy wine. Red-berry flavors are there but lack balancing acidity.
Fruity and juicy, this forward, no-wood wine will develop fast. Tannins await behind the attractive red-berry flavors. Drink this wine from Blaye native Anne Venancy from 2020.
Firm and structured, this mostly Merlot blend has a dry core of tannins. It also shows a bitter edge of extraction that will be hard to soften.
This smoky wine is hard around the edges. It has concentration but whether the fruit will have a chance amid all this structure is debatable. It seems to have a dry future.

While this biodynamic wine has a juicy element, it also suffers from highly extracted tannins that give a bitter character and hard edge. These could soften, although the wine will likely remain tough.

This 90% Merlot wine reflects the generous texture and ripe red-berry fruits of the vintage. It is already showing signs of maturing, softening the fruit and moving towards some secondary flavors. Drink this wine from 2019.
Already almost drinkable, this ripe, generously tannic wine is packed with bold black fruits that follow through to acidity and a juicy aftertaste. Full but not too heavy, drink from 2020.

Produced from 90% Merlot and 10% Malbec, this wine is made by two young brothers. It is ripe and structured, still young of course, but with delicious ripely fruity potential. Black-currant and berry flavors are lifted by acidity and held firmly by the structure. Drink from 2019.

This wine comes from a small estate in Blaye whose origins go back to the 18th century. The wine is still young with some lean fruit that needs to fill out the structure-a structure that is all there with firm tannins and a dry core. Drink this firm wine from 2019.

Vines situated close to the fortified citadel of Blaye have produced this bright and shiny 2014. With its clear red-berry fruits, black currants and acidity, it is immediately attractive. The tannins, a great support to the fruit, promise some aging. Drink now, or, better yet, wait until 2018.

This blend of 75% Merlot and 25% Cabernet Sauvignon is light, bright and crisp. It has red fruits and perfumed acidity along with a softly tannic aftertaste. It is not a wine for aging long so drink from 2018.

This ripe wine is dense with firm tannins and bright with red-berry fruits. Dominated by 60% rich Merlot, it is structured while never losing sight of its fruit and spice. The wine is still developing, so don't drink before 2018.

As with so many wines from Blaye, this is dominated by Merlot. That gives a ripe full wine that is spicy and full of black-plum fruits. Firm tannins still show through the fruits that are balanced by acidity. The wine still needs to age, so drink from 2018.

The wine has some maturity although its tannins are still very present. It has some juicy black-currant flavor that is shot through with the dry core. The aftertaste brings out more acidity and a more juicy character. Drink from 2018.

A fruity, tank-aged wine that has spice, stalky black-currant fruit and some dry tannins. It is juicy and lightly perfumed with plenty of acidity to keep it crisp. It takes its name from the beehive shaped wells (puit) typical of the north of the Gironde. Drink from 2018.

This Bayle-Carreau wine, one of five fifth-generation family estates, is balanced between the dry core of tannins and the ripe black fruit. With acidity and a fine structure, it has great potential. As it develops the wine will show richness as well as concentration. Drink from 2018.

Under the watchful eye of consultant Eric Delacroix, the Bazin twins (Thierry and Odile) created a wine that is dark and dense. This is a young wine with good potential. Its black fruits and solid tannins are rich and structured. Acidity and ripeness go together and will let the wine develop well. Drink from 2019.

This is a ripe, spicy and full-bodied wine from the Robin group of producers created by Grand Moulin's Jean-Francois Renaud in Blaye. The wine has both structure and rich blackberry fruit. The tannins are dusty, spicy and with fine acidity to balance. Drink this fine wine from 2019.

This is a rounded wine, full of perfumed fruit and wood flavors. It has a dense texture with ripe, dusty tannins and fine acidity. From the Alliance Bourg co-op, this full-bodied and rich Bordeaux blend will be a fine wine from 2019.

This Alliance Bourg co-op wine is packed with minty new-wood aromas, this has the potential to be a smooth, polished wine. The blend is 70% Merlot, 20% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Cabernet Franc. Firm tannins at this stage do not mask the ripe blackberry fruits. Give this wine until 2019 before drinking.

Producer Cyril Trias works with Alliance Bourg cooperative on this Merlot-dominated wine. It is ripe with rich blackberry fruits. It has spice, a dry core of tannins and a touch of chocolate. With its wood, juicy fruit and acidity, it will develop well and will be ready to drink from 2019.

While this Alliance Bourg wine is dry at the moment, this will be a rich and ripe wine with plenty of potential. It has tannins that are balanced by the spicy red-berry fruit and acidity. Drink from 2019.

While the wood flavors are prominent, they don't mask the ripe berry fruits in this Merlot-dominant blend. Blaye sister-brother team of Marie-Pierre et Pierre-Charles Dartier produced a wine with a rich character. It is full of wood spice, hints of mint and acidity. Drink from 2019.

This is a firm wine, dry and with tight tannins. The fruit weight is still developing and the wine needs time to fully realize its potential. Given time, the fruit will become rich and full. Denis Noël and his kids run the estate, which has been in the family since 1800. Drink from 2019.

This wine from Blaye sister-brother team of Marie-Pierre et Pierre-Charles Dartier is perfumed, ripe with black fruits and with a generous smooth texture. With the hint of tannin from the wood aging and the black-plum fruits, it will be a rich, generous wine. Drink from 2018.

While this young wine is dry now, it has good potential with rich fruits developing well. Dark and firm at the moment, it will become a generous rounded wine as it ages. The 30-acre Etienne Barre and Christophe Reboul Salze estate is managed by the Stephane Derenoncourt team. Drink from 2019.

Fruity and spicy, this is a finely wrought wine. Structured and concentrated, it will develop well, giving a solid wine with tannins as well as blackberry fruits. Drink this Sébastian and Nicolas Carreau wine from 2019.

The Jonck family's wine is dense and still young with firm tannins. It has excellent potential because the ripe berry fruits are right there to give richness and flesh out the tannins. Spice and acidity fill the background. Drink this fine wine from 2019.

Blaye sister-brother team of Marie-Pierre et Pierre-Charles Dartier are hitting the mark with this certified sustainable wine. With touches of wood aging giving the wine a minty character, this is stylish and ripe. It is still young, while showing plenty of signs of good potential, black-currant fruits and richness. Drink from 2018.

A ripe and smooth wine, full of dark fruits and tannins that are embedded in the richness. There is a balancing juicy character in this fruity wine. Dominated by ripe Merlot, the wine will develop quickly and will be ready to drink from 2017.

The wine from Denis Coudroy's 10 acres of vines is perfumed from new wood, with a polished character and bright fruit flavors. Underneath the wood, there is plenty of black-currant juiciness and fresh acidity. Drink this attractive wine from 2019.

A wine that has layers of new wood as well as blackberry fruits. With firm, young tannins at this stage and also plenty of fruit, this Noël family wine is likely to develop into a rich wine. Drink from 2019.

This is a dry wine, packed with tannins at this stage. With concentrated fruits and spice in the background, it will become a rich structured wine. This Merlot/Cabernet Sauvignon wine was vinified for 12 months in French oak and six months in underground cement vats-aiming for drinkability for at least 10 years. But go ahead and drink the wine starting from 2019.

The wine is both dense and fruity. It has fine tannins that are dark and concentrated. The berry flavors are balanced with acidity and touches of wood-aging spice. Give it until 2018 and consider opening for an hour before tasting.

Perfumed with wood flavors, this is a dry wine at this stage. Let the black-currant fruitiness from the organic Merlot/Cabernet Sauvignon grapes come through before drinking. Acidity and a fresh character promise well. Wait until 2019.

Stephane Heurlier makes a generous yet structured wine that's full of fruit. It has plenty of spice and black currant layered with a touch of chocolate and coffee. Let the wine mature and drink from 2019.
A ripe and spicy wine, this is structured with black-currant fruits and lively acidity. It is still very young: its exuberant fruitiness likely to calm as it matures. Give this ripe wine until 2019.

The wine is soft, ripe and fruity with fine tannins and plenty of red-berry fruit flavors. Structured and spicy, it will develop well into a concentrated ripe wine. Jean-Michel Baudet's Blaye estate vineyards were the first to be certified sustainable by Terra Vitis. Drink from 2018.
This wine is dense with tannins while not losing sight of the ripe berry fruits. The balance is coming together well, giving a structured wine that also has fine fresh black fruits. Drink from 2019.

The seventh generation of the Carreau family has produced this rich full-bodied and structured wine. It has dense tannins as well as plenty of ripe red fruits. The structure suggests the wine will continue to age, so drink this ripe wine from 2017.

This certified organic wine from Damien Lorteau is juicy with attractive blackberry fruit. Spice and warm tannins (aged 12 months in barrel) give it a rich structure. It will have a fine future-a ripe wine with plenty of fruitiness. Drink from 2019.

Vincent and Ludivine l'Amouller, the estate's fourth generation, named this wine after the sailboat of the ancestor who moored in Blaye and bought the vineyard. The 2014 vintage, certified organic, is firm while also rich with fruit. The wine is going to generous, ripe and full of concentration. Drink this attractive wine with its good potential from 2019.

The wood flavors are still prominent in this spicy wine. Heavily influenced by rich Merlot, the wine is lightly structured and more about juicy red fruits. Tannins in the back give enough shape, although it will be ready to drink from early 2017.

This is a fragrant, spicy wine that is shot through with red fruits and fine acidity. The 95% Merlot and 5% Cabernet Sauvignon blend is still firm with its tannins although the acidity and bright fruit are well in balance. Drink from 2018.
Still dry, the wine is structured with dense tannins and a concentrated structure. That means that it needs time to develop and allow the fruit to speak. Give it until 2019.

From a estate in the Marmet family since 1990, the wine has ripe Merlot flavors that give a generous character. Big, bold fruitiness dominates this wine whose structure is firm while smooth. Drink starting from 2019.

Closed and firm at this early stage, the wine from Jean-Michel Bergeron has good potential. It is rich with plenty of black-currant fruit as well as dry tannins. Give this wine its time and wait until 2019.
The Vignobles Bourdillas brothers' wine is fruity with black currant fruits and bright acidity. Fresh with a crisp texture and light tannins, it will be ready to drink by 2017.
A ripe wine from Haure Jany, this is dense with wood and tannins. The black-currant fruit is masked at this stage with a powerful dry core. Let this soften before drinking, so wait until 2019.
The wine is dry and structured with firm tannins that are masking the fruit. It is a concentrated wine, firm and dense. Let this wine develop and wait to drink until 2019.

A fruity wine with fresh acidity and light tannins, this is going to be ripe with a juicy character and bright tannins. After four years of conversion by Vincent and Ludivine l'Amouller, the estate's fourth generation, the 2014 vintage is now certified organic.

This 10-acre vineyard in the Carreau portfolio is surrounded by a stone wall (which is unusual for Bordeaux). The wine with its firm tannins is still very young. But with a structure and with balanced fruitiness it will develop well. There is plenty of fine, juicy acidity at the end. Drink from 2019.

Crisp and fruity, this is a wine full of red currant and blackberry flavors. It does have a tannic structure that will allow the wine to develop along with the acidity. In the family for three-generations, the estate is now run by Denis Hazane. Drink from 2018.
This is firm, with dense fruits and ripe tannins. It has concentration as well as plenty of red fruits. Drink this potentially rich wine from Alliance Bourg from 2018.

Fresh and fruity, Jacques Chardat's wine is packed with red-berry fruit along with a dry core. The tannins and acidity will develop well as the wine ages to produce a ripe, fruity wine. Drink from 2018.

The wine is structured with firm tannins as well as ripe fruit. Juicy and concentrated, it has a spicy character that comes from the wood aging. In the Mayé Eymery family since 1854, the wine is from six parcels on the estate. Give this fresh as well as rich wine until 2019.
Winemaker Madeleine Jautard has produced a soft, juicy wine, packed with ripe fruits. There is a touch of spice as well to give the wine its structure. Drink this wine from 2018.

This is a structured wine from 96% Merlot and 4% Cabernet Sauvignon that has plenty of fruit. With some firm tannins as well as concentrated blackberry fruit, it is going to be a fine wine. It was created under the direction of consultant Stéphane Derenoncourt's team. Start drinking from 2019.

The wine is dry, dense although with a fine fruity potential. Underneath the dry texture, the wine is full of black-currant fruitiness. The vineyard is managed by Jacques Chardat and winemaking by Grégory Dalla Longa. Drink from 2019.
The wine is structured with concentrated tannins and dense fruit. It has spice, wood-aging flavors and a firm aftertaste. That means the wine needs time, so wait until 2019.
This wine is ripe and potentially rich, but is firm at this stage. With its dark tannins and dense structure, it will age well. Drink from 2019.
This is a soft, fruity 80% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Sauvignon wine. With gentle tannins and red fruit flavors, it is developing well, becoming a juicy and fruity wine.
A perfumed fruity wine, this has a light structure along with its forward red fruits. Acidity and juicy fruitiness complete this attractive, ready to drink wine.
From a 17-acre Merlot-dominated vineyard, this is a dry wine, where the tannins dominate the fruit. The wine has a bitter edge from too much extraction. The hints of fruit are not quite enough.
The wine, with its dry tannins, is dense while unfocussed. It will remain tannin dominated.

The wine is packed with toasty wood flavors that give it a bitter character. The wood masks the fruit although there are hints of black-currant freshness. The wine needs time to come together, so wait until 2019.

Bernard Larrat's wine is dry at this stage, although with hints of ripe black-currant fruit and acidity. The potential is there with juicy flavors and fruitiness already developing well. Drink from 2019.
The wine smells of over-ripe fruit and this sensation continues through the palate. The fruit and the tannins don't coincide.
This Merlot/Cabernet Franc blend is a tight closed wine showing tannins rather than fruit. It will remain this way.
This Alliance Bourg wine is dry and firm with its concentrated tannins. Too much extraction has left a bitter character. It will remain a wine that is tough.
Shooting for wine that will age for at least 15 years, this has too much wood for its own good. Dark and spicy with tough toast, it will likely remain that way. Somebody tried too hard.
This is a lean wine, all tannins and missing fruit. It is dry and showing considerable hard extraction. It will soften, but not much.

This wine from Bruno Martin's 3.3-acre vineyard is going to be a fresh and fruity. Already it has a fine juicy character and plenty of red fruits. Crisp acidity at the end confirms this bright character.
The wine is juicy with red-fruit flavors. The tannins are firm and concentrated giving a layer of dryness under the fruit. Give this perfumed wine from Luc Schweitzer until 2019.
The spicy wood is prominent here. It balances the red-berry fruits and bright acidity. That makes for a perfumed, juicy wine that will finish fresh and crisp.
This Dubois family wine is soft and fruity with attractive blackberry fruits and light tannins. Drink this generous wine from 2018.
This wine is juicy with wood and spice flavors. It has plenty of acidity to balance the tannins while the fruit will give it an attractive freshness as it develops. Drink from 2018.
This is a crisp, fresh wine with red-currant fruits and light tannins from the Alliance Bourg co-op. It is juicy and fruity, likely to develop quickly to give a light, bright wine.
This is a dry wine, dense with tannins while also having plenty of rich fruits underneath. Solid and structured, it will become a firm wine with ripe fruit flavors. Drink from 2019.
While the wine is dry at this young stage, it has fine potential. Generous fruits and firm tannins give it richness and a juicy character. Drink the wine from 2018.
This is a fresh and juicy organic wine with attractive acidity and just the right balance of tannins. Drink this wine soon, certainly from 2018.

Aged both in wooden tanks and wood barrels, this smooth, silky rich wine is impressive. A blend of one-third each of Merlot, Malbec and Cabernet Franc, it is dense, dark and spicy. Juicy black fruits give the wine its ripe character. At the same time the structure keeps the opulent fruitiness in check. The wine is showing well now, although it will be better kept until 2018.

Produced from a selection of grapes, this is a bold, fruity wine that has rich tannins and a generous structure. It is all about the black-fruit flavors with balanced acidity and just hints of toast. It is now a delicious, mature wine from a fine year. Drink now.

From one of the oldest estates in Blaye, this smooth wine is rich and packed with blackberry fruits. It has a mint character as well as spice. It is a juicy, powerful wine that will need to age. Drink from 2019.

Dating back to the 16th century, this estate's 52-acre vineyard faces the Gironde estuary. The wine is dark, firm and concentrated. The tannins are firm, and hard edged. The acidity and the smoky character of the wine make a fine balance with its tough, young side. Drink from 2019.

This is a ripe wine showing the fruit and freshness of the vintage. That black-currant fruit character is filled out with spicy red fruits, balanced tannins and a jammy, red-berry texture. The wine will be ready to drink from 2017.

A blend with over half Merlot, this has developed into a ripe, smooth wine from a fine vintage. It has just the right amount of dusty structure to sustain the rich blackberry fruits and smoky wood flavors. It has a juicy, ripe aftertaste. Drink now.
Still with its young tannins intact, the wine is firm and structured. It has spice, mint and black-currant fruits under the tight texture. It will still age so wait, if you want, for another year.

This is an attractive, soft and fruity wine. With gentle tannins and a touch of spice to balance the red fruits, it is developing into a juicy wine. Lightly smoky at the end, it will be ready to drink from 2017.

This ripe wine has light tannins to go with its red currant and blackberry fruits. The blend is 70% Merlot, 27% Cabernet Sauvignon and 3% Cabernet Franc. It is developing fast. With its acidity and gentle tannins it will be ready from 2017.

Rich and concentrated, this blend is mainly Merlot, with a little Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec. The alcohol shows in the weight of the wine, but the freshness is still very present. Powerful, dark and still young, the wine will be best from 2017.

This fruity, black-currant-flavored wine comes from a blend of Merlot and Cabernets Sauvignon and Franc. A strong, smoky tannin character lies under the fruit and makes the wine both structured and fresh, with blackberry acidity at the end. This promises some aging; drink from 2017. An Alliance Bourg member.

Ripe and smoky, this offers great fruit that bursts through the tannic structure. The 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon blend is packed with red plum and blackberry fruits that are based upon a solid structure. This will be a fine wine; just wait until 2017. Producer Arnaud Pomme works with co-operative Alliance Bourg.

A ripe, smoky and still-tannic wine, this is solidly structured. A dense, dry core shows some sign of extraction although the blackberry fruits are developing well. As the wine ages, it will bring out the balance between acidity and structure. Drink from 2017. Owner Cyril Trias works with Alliance Bourg co-operative on his wines.

Rich, ripe and full-bodied, this is a Merlot/Cabernet Sauvignon/Malbec blend. Juicy acidity and berry fruits are integrated into the firm structure. A smoky, dry wood-laden background gives the wine good texture. Drink from 2016. Xavier Carreau, Alain Jourdan and Cyril Jourdan, the latest generation, run the family's five estates.

Firm and with dark tannins, this wine has great potential. Ripe berry fruits and a concentrated structure are already well balanced with acidity cutting through. As it matures, this wine with its dense structure will develop well. Drink from 2017. Enologist Sebastien and vineyard manager Nicolas are the latest Carreau generation managing family estates.

Powerfully structured, this is a dense wine, with layers of ripe fruit as well as tannins. It is concentrated, firm and showing its structure. The black plum fruit flavors from the 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon blend give weight and a broad character to the aftertaste. Drink from 2017. Produced by Alliance Bourg.

Still dominated by its tannins, this is a full, structured wine. Dense and with fragrant acidity and black currant flavors, it has a way to go before it is ready to drink. Wait until 2017. The estate is an Alliance Bourg co-operative member.

Ripe and fruity, this red-berry flavored wine has good acidity and a crisp, bright texture. The tannins are now well integrated into the fruit, giving a structured, yet fresh, aftertaste. Drink now. In the Chéty family for eight generations, the vineyards were changed to organic in 2011 by sons Olivier and Emmanuel (enologist), who also made major renovations to the winery.
This wine is all crisp red currants and acidity. Fresh, fruity and lightly textured, it is a wine to drink young, from 2016.

This lightly oaked wine is already balanced with some attractive dusty tannins and red currant fruit flavors. It is bright with acidity and with a fresh, fruity aftertaste. Drink from 2016. This is a Carreau family estate.

Flavors of bitter extraction spoil this wine, giving an unnecessarily hard character and masking the fruit. It probably will not soften much. The blend is 79% Merlot, 20% Cabernet Sauvignon and 1% Cabernet Franc. Produced by Alliance Bourg.

While the tannins here are dry, this wine has enough fruit to show its potential. Blackberry flavors are ripe, cut with acidity and a juicy texture. The wine needs time, so drink from 2017. Enologist Sebastien and vineyard manager Nicolas are the latest generation managing the Carreau family estates.

Darkly tannic, this wine has a dense structure that needs time. It is firm, dry and concentrated. The fruit potential is still developing so keep this wine until 2017. Enologist Sebastien and vineyard manager Nicolas are the latest generation managing the Carreau family estates.
Firm but with juicy fruit, this 80% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Sauvignon blend is a solid, still young, wine. The aftertaste is tough and packed with acidity.
This wine has too much tannin for its own good. It's tough and bitter, showing wood and extraction. In this difficult Bordeaux vintage, the vineyard produced less than half what is normal.
This wine has fresh acidity and attractive black currant fruit flavors. They are given a hard ride by the dark and bitter tannins and dry texture. This is a Carreau family wine.

This wine is concentrated, with fruit that seems too ripe. Jammy berry flavors are mixed in with dry tannins and a firm backdrop. It's solid, although not quite balanced. The estate was founded in 1967 by Philippe Raguenot; daughters Emmanuelle and Marie-Pierre took over in 1997.

Heavy wood aromas from new French oak barrels show equally strongly as dark chocolate flavors on the palate from this 50/50 Merlot/Malbec blend. The wine, tiny production from 2.5 acres, is all wood, very firm and tough. Only the acidity suggests a potential fruitiness. This estate has been in the Noël family since 1800.
Jammy fruits conflict with a firm tannic structure. This wine is not yet balanced and needs a lighter touch. Producer is Jean Paul Barre.
This ripe, smoky wine is full of black fruits and soft, generous tannins. It is rich, juicy with black plum juice and berry jelly flavors that are still young and fresh. Age this wine until 2017.
This perfumed wine from a great year is rich in both fruit and structure, solid with tannins as well as ripe fruit. It is still youthful, dense and powerful. Wait and drink from 2018.

Structured and still dry with young tannins, this concentrated wine has the potential of fresh black currant fruits. For the moment, it is dark, showing some bitter chocolate flavors that need to soften. Drink from 2017.

Situated two miles north of the castle of Blaye, this estate has produced an obviously wood-aged, heavily extracted wine. At this stage, this wine is all tannins, smoky acidity and structure. It will always be concentrated with wood, although this will soften.
Ripe and luscious, this reflects the fruitiness of the vintage very well. It has tannins that will develop, although the blackberry fruits and juicy acidity dominate at the moment. Drink from 2018.

Big, full-bodied and very much a product of the 2010 vintage, this structured, generous wine needs time. The dry tannins are still prominent, giving a tough edge to the more generous, concentrated fruits. Drink from 2018.

From selected parcels on the Bertinerie vineyard, this is still a young, firmly structured wine. Red berry fruits offer a contrast to the solid tannins and rich texture. The wood aging still shows, giving a spicy character that will integrate as the wine matures. Drink from 2017.

The wood-aging flavors are strong although not too dominant. They ride well with the solid fruit tannins, flavorsome blackberry fruits and firm, smoky aftertaste. This balanced wine will need some aging; drink from 2016.

Hand-sorting and 18 months of aging is the key here. This 80% Merlot blend with 15% Cabernet Sauvignon and 5% Cabernet Franc offers a generously proportioned balance of tannins and black fruits. It has full-bodied character, packed with berry fruits and rich acidity. With all these elements, it will develop well. Drink from 2017.

Structured and fruity, this 25-acre vineyard of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc has produced a blend that is solid and with a good future. It has black fruits and firm tannins along with well-judged wood aging (six to eight months). It is ripe, with attractive juicy flavors and spice. Drink from 2017.

This is fruity and juicy with good acidity and fresh berry fruits. The 90% Merlot and 10% Cabernet Sauvignon blend has the right amount of tannic character, showing structure that brings out ripe red fruits and indicates good potential. Drink from 2017.

Big and juicy, this is an attractive blend of 70% Merlot, 20% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Malbec with a promising future. It has ripe berry fruits, touches of spice and ginger. The tannins are firm, dusty and dry while allowing plenty of room for the fruit. It will develop well; drink from 2018.

This rich, concentrated wine is velvet smooth, with tannins enveloped by ripe berry and plum fruits. Wood aging has added to the the rounded character. Despite its approachability, it will age well, so the wine is best drunk from 2018.

From 7.5 acres of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, this is a rich wine, very perfumed and with layers of ripe fruit. It is lightly structured, full of red berries with a firm tannic character in the background. Under winemaker Olivier Dauga, the wine needs to age but has all the fruit potential there. Drink from 2018.

This special selection, tight-cropped from 30 acres of 100% Merlot, is ripe and rich. This is a smoky and fruity wine, in barrel for 14 months. It has ripe black fruits and rich, dense structure. Spice and toast balance the fruit, giving an impressive sense of generosity. Drink from 2017.

Here's a solid wine full of both tannins and dark fruits. New oak barrels give a spicy character while supporting the fruitiness. A blend of 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon from only 10 acres, it is developing into a rich wine that still needs time. Drink this impressive wine from 2018.

Made from old vines, this complex and structured wine brings out the richness and ripe tannins of 2010. It's firm although the fruit concentration is what shows most strongly. It's an impressive, juicy, red-fruited wine that will age. Drink from 2017.

The ninth generation of the Dublois family goes for tight cropping on only 7.5 acres for Nectar (95% Merlot, 5% Cabernet Sauvignon). Layers of wood dominate this wine. However, it does promise fruit as well, shown by the weight and richness. So it's a wine for a pause, to allow the intense spice and new wood flavors to die down. Firm and dry now, it will be worth the wait. Drink from 2018.

Attractive and smooth, this is a ripe, broad wine with its soft, juicy red berry fruits and supporting firm tannins. Balanced and fruity, it is ready to drink, finishing with a crisp texture of acidity.

A wine that is well balanced with attractive ripe berry fruits and generous tannins. It has weight and richness, allowing room for the development of both the structure and the fruits. Drink from 2017.

Bold and fruity, this blend is ripe, full of juicy black fruits, with a core of dry tannin. It is going to be a delicious wine with great fruitiness and attractive acidity. A mineral element at the end will allow it to develop well. This is a second wine of Jean-Michel Baudet, fifth-generation winemaker. Drink from 2018.

Situated on limestone and clay (peyredoulle means hard rock in an old dialect), the wine offers spice and sweet fruit flavors, balancing wood and fruitiness. The classic Merlot, Malbec, Cabernet Franc, Cabernet Sauvignon and Petit Verdot blend has considerable potential, allowing plenty of room for the fruit and the wood tannin flavors to integrate. Drink from 2017.

Alain and Céline Vidal's second brand (they also own Château Dubraud) is a fruity blend of Merlot (60%), Cabernet Sauvignon (25%) and Cabernet Franc (15%) although the smoky wood flavors also have an important place. Red berries and black currants partner with acidity and firm tannins. The wine is still developing so drink from 2016.

The mix of spice and fruit gives a ripe feel and shows good potential. With 75% Merlot, 15% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Cabernet Franc, it has a juicy backdrop boosted by wood-aging flavors. It needs to age, so drink from 2018. The estate has been in the Dop family for 150 years.

A year's barrel aging has given this firm and very rich wine a spicy character. That marries with the licorice and bitter chocolate to give a ripe, extracted and dense wine. It needs a few years to bring out more of the juicy plum fruitiness. Drink from 2017.

This rich wine has very ripe fruit, layers of juicy berries and black plums and a broad brush of acidity and tannins. It may not be subtle, but it is likely to be a full-bodied, enjoyable wine from 2017.

Full of delicious fruits, this is a bright, red berry blend of Merlot (90%) and Malbec (10%). It has lively acidity allied to a more formal tannic structure that gives a firm, age-worthy feel to the wine. Drink from 2017.

The wine's color has already passed the young and fruity stage, hinting at the aging that's apparent on the palate. So the bright fruits have diminished, leaving a wine that is round and hinting at the wood aging. It can be drunk now.

This Cuvée honors a sailor who, in 1919, docked his boat, La Favorite, at Blaye in the Gironde estuary and bought the property. It is still owned by the l'Amouller family. Juicy and fruity, this wine is immediately attractive and accessible. Red fruits, soft tannins and a bite of acidity all contribute to the ready-to-drink taste.

This spicy 100% Merlot wine has tangy black fruits as well as dense texture. It is ripe and very juicy, with intense acidity. It needs to relax (25% new oak barrels; 25% one to two years, the rest in tanks), so drink from 2017.

This is ripe and juicy with friendly acidity and tannins from 10 months' wood aging in two- to five-year-old barrels. Black fruits are coupled with minerality to give a wine that is both structured and with plenty of generous fruitiness. The property is run by the seventh generation of the Carreau family.

Night harvesting on the highest hill in Blaye is tricky but the Chety family pulls it off. Ripe and juicy, this is a ready-to-drink wine. It has berry fruits cut with acidity and with a firm line in spicy wood from barrels one- to three-years-old. The tannins give a solid foundation and aging potential. Drink from 2017.
The wine has a hard extracted edge, with bitter tannins that are dominating the fruitiness. It needs to soften and bring out the berry fruits, although the wine will always have a tough character.
This wine is soft and juicy with 12 months in barrel. It has rounded tannins and perfumed berry fruits. What it misses is the acidity, leaving an unbalanced wine.
The wine is all toast and smoky wood flavors though it spent only six to eight months in oak. It is extracted and hard, with little fruit.

Overripe, jammy fruits and dry tannins are an odd combination. They don't work in this wine that has a hot character. This is the first vineyard in Blaye certified by Terra Vitis for sustainable viticulture.

Vanilla and caramel flavors dominate this wine after 12 months in French oak. That means that the fruit is really not allowed to shine. It is firm, very dry and all about spice. A pepper flavor from the alcohol leaves a burn in the mouth.
The over-exuberance of wood aging spoils this wine. With strong spice and equally tannic elements, it's all about the skeleton and not about the flesh of the fruit.

The wine is ripe and soft with a body of tannin that sits uneasily within this jammy character. The blend (Merlot 75%, Cabernet Franc 25%, Malbec 5%) was aged 30% in barrel and 70% in stainless steel tanks. It is unbalanced and likely to remain so.
Juicy and spicy flavors give a wine that layers fruit and ginger. Blackberries are the dominant fruit while the spice adds a bite that is almost exotic.
The wine is perfumed, spicy with dense tannins. It has a hard-edged structure, tough with the ripe fruit still underneath. Vines are an average of 14 years old.
Smoky and toasty, this is a structured wine. It has layers of black currant fruits, fresh acidity as well as firm tannins that overlay the juicy fruitiness. It needs to age. Drink from 2016.

Firm and dry, it's packed with as much tannin as fruit. It has a dark, structured character that's shot through with mint and black currant flavors. The aftertaste is dense and solid. Drink from 2017.

With some years under its belt, this has become a ripe, full and smooth wine. It shows attractive acidity as well as some firm tannins, but these fit well into the juicy black plum fruits and fresh aftertaste. Drink now.
Bright and fruity, it has soft tannins layered with black currant fruitiness and a dry core. It's juicy, ripe and developing well. Drink from 2016.
This wood-laden wine shows more toast than fruit at this stage. It does have plenty of blackberry flavors for the future, giving texture to the firm structure. Drink from 2016.
This dry wine is strongly dominated by tannins. It is structured, firm and hard-edged. Without the fresh acidity at the end, it would be a tough proposition.

Very firm tannins dominate this potentially ripe, juicy wine. So while it is structured with some bitter chocolate flavors from extraction, it also has red berry fruits and fresh acidity at the end. It will mature quickly, so drink from 2016.

A rich wine that has weight, solid tannins and ripe black currant flavors. It conveys a strong sense of structure without losing sight of a stylish fruitiness and firm texture. With acidity cutting through the richness, it will age well. Drink from 2016.

The wine has some of the typical freshness of 2011 but it seems on the thin side. Black currant flavors run alongside high acidity, and the tannins show strongly. The aftertaste brings out more tight, mineral acidity.

An attractively aromatic wine, full of open fruitiness. It has layers of black currant fruit that go with the fresh acidity, plus a touch of herbs that are followed by firm tannins. Juicy and ready to drink from 2015.
Hugely tannic, this formidable wine has great weight, richness and a dark and dense structure. Juicy berry fruits, sweet plum flavors and a dry, concentrated backdrop promise aging. Drink from 2018.

A powerful wine for the vintage, it is rich and opulent. It shows strong tannins, licorice and dark chocolate and super-ripe berry fruits. At the same time, it is elegant, balanced and just needs time. Drink from 2018.

Showing the rich fruit of the vintage, it has warm red berry juiciness and an added smoky flavor. The wine is round yet still structured enough to balance its ripe surface. Drink this wine soon, best from 2015.
A smooth, rich wine, it is full of opulent black fruits. It has weight, solid tannins and a great juicy swather of fruitiness. Aromatic and ripe, it is already developing well. Drink from 2017.

Serious and tannic, this wine is slow to show its virtues. It does have black currant and plum juice flavors that are coming through the dense, dry structure. It needs to age, so don't drink before 2017.
This big, ripe, Merlot-dominated wine has great black fruits that envelop the firmer, smoky tannins. Generous and rich, it's already an attractive wine but one which will age. Drink from 2016.
A dry, tannic wine that is firmly structured. A sense of extraction masks the light and fresh black currant fruitiness. Give it until 2017 to soften.

This ripe, fruity, juicy wine shows both the richness as well as the freshness of the vintage. Forward and fruity with black currants and red berries, it's already a delicious wine with dry tannins lending some structure . Drink now.
There is rich, warm fruitiness here from ripe blackberries and plums. The wine has weight and concentration, but is framed with dry tannins. The wine should develop well, so drink from 2015.
Light, fruity and fragrant, this is an attractive, crisp wine that highlights red-berry fruits and soft acidity. It's a wine to drink now.

Big, fruity and juicy, this is a wine for drinking soon. It has lively acidity, a strong black-currant fruit character and light tannins. Already well integrated, it's a wine that accentuates freshness.

The wine develops slowly in the glass, closed at first and then bringing on ripe fruits and firm tannins. There is a definite dryness here, solid, textured and darkly structured. It is meant for aging, so don't drink before 2016.

Soft for the vintage, here is a wine that has a ripe, opulent feel. Its tannins are fully integrated into the rich, forward blackberry fruits that are ripe and generous. The wine is not for long-term aging. Drink until 2019.

This is a solid and structured wine that is lightened by its juicy acidity. Black currant fruits dominate, giving a fresh character to the wine. The tannins that show through do promise medium-term aging. Drink from 2014.

Possibly too rich, this is a full, sumptuous wine. It has great weight, density, a smooth, wood-aged character that shows through the sweet plums. For what it is, a very rich wine that shows some pepper alcohol-it offers a juicy character and ageability. Drink from 2016.

This rich and integrated wine is full of ripe berry fruit and firm tannins. It is a full, concentrated wine, densely textured and structured. There is a good sense of juiciness behind the youthful, firm surface. Give this fine, great-value wine at least four years.

A rich, bold wine full of wood flavors that are already well integrated with the ripe fruit and solid tannins. The wine is dense, while having a surface polish of smooth fruitiness. Give the wine 3-5 years.
Ripe and sweetly fruity, this is a black-currant and berry-flavored wine, with balanced juiciness and a judicious use of wood. Full-bodied, it's likely to age well over the medium term.

High amounts of new wood hit both the aromas and the structure of the wine. It has firm weight, dry, smoky tannins and a bitter-chocolate character. It's very dense and very dry, although with the potential to soften and reveal more attractive, juicy fruit.
Firm and tannic, but it promises a ripe, fruity future. It's dense and concentrated, with blackberry fruit giving it a full, ripe character. Age 4-6 years.
With ample acidity and juicy black fruit, this is a light, refreshing, already fragrant wine. It's bright and lively, just hinting at black chocolate and blackberry fruit.
Ripe and spicy, this is a rich, full-bodied wine packed with sweet blackberry fruit as well as bitter licorice. It shows very good potential for the next 4-5 years.
This soapy, unfocused wine has tannins and red berry fruit but little structure. The fruit shows a green streak that will not improve.
A firm, licorice-flavored wine, with bitter notes and a peppery character that shows through the fruit. It feels extracted and hot.
An attractive, fruity wine with black-currant and red-berry juiciness followed by a lightly tannic character. It's a classic for the vintage-light and fruity.
This balanced, juicy, fruity wine has refreshing red-berry fruit as well as solid tannins to back it up. An already attractive wine, this fruity number is likely to age quickly.

A big, ripe and juicy wine packed with black fruit notes and laced with acidity. The tannins offer a contrast to the fruitiness, bringing balance and structure. This is an impressive wine, the smoky aftertaste bringing out the wood aging.
Densely tannic while also fruity, this is a product of ripe fruits that give a black currant flavor as well as a solid structure. The acidity gives great lift to the end of this finely made wine.

A packed wine, its ripe fruits are a warm pleasure. It has all the structure of the year but in fine measure, lending density and richness to the palate. It's a wine for aging; give it at least five years.

A eucalyptus oil aroma offers a smooth and fragrant introduction to this ripe, rich and juicy wine. Its polished feel works, offering both richness and solid tannins. It's for aging over at least five years.
There's a great structure here, and the wine is rich with prominent, firm tannins. It has the long-term potential to be an impressively structured wine, with the fruit balancing it out.

A wine that's straight down the line, firmly structured and with solid fruit for the future. There is weight and richness, a sense of power waiting to show in the future. With its density, anticipate aging this wine for at least 6-7 years.
Attractive mints and wood tannins are balanced by generous blackberry fruit and a chocolate flavor that lends extra richness. It has great aging potential; keep this concentrated wine for 5-6 years.

This is a big, tannic wine, where the weight of the fruit complements the firm structure, making it a powerful wine with concentration and the potential for good aging. There are hints of the juicy black fruits to come; give this wine at least five years.

A big, bold, fruity wine, this has great tannins, ripe black-currant fruit and an attractive sense of structure. It has all the juiciness and freshness of 2010, but is a wine for aging over 3-4 years.
Big, bold and juicy, with ripe black fruits that dominate the rich tannins. The power and concentration both promise a good future for this solid, full-bodied wine, so keep for 4-5 years.

Firmly tannic yet with enough sense of juicy fruit to act as a balance, this is a fine, rich wine, showing power and concentration with a solid, ripe structure. Give this wine at least five years to soften and round out.
While it has sufficient tannin, the wine also has a feeling of generous black currant and berry fruits. It's dry with considerable concentration, but it's future looks good, so keep for 5-6 years.
This mint- and new-wood-flavored wine boasts ripe tannins and lush fruit. It feels weighty, perhaps almost too rich, while the tannins have a bitter-chocolate edge to them.
Dusty tannins push to the front, resulting in a firm, wood-aged wine that shows smokiness, ripe blackberry flavors and a firm core. This should be at its best in 2-3 years.

A dry, very firm wine, currently dominated by hard tannins. Woody flavors and a dense texture are present characteristics, with the fruit less in evidence. It could soften, because there is a hint of juiciness at the end.

Rich, concentrated and fruity, this wine is ripe and full of blackberry fruits with hints of strawberry. Its tannins are a soft, round envelope for the fruit. Expect this wine to age relatively quickly over the next three years.
Aromas and flavors of rhubarb and red pepper dominate, resulting in a wine that is sharp and unbalanced.
A diffuse wine without focus. The tannins and the fruit are some way apart, while the final flavor is dry and tough.
Bell peppers and green herbs as well as dark tannins are the main characters of this very dry, bitter wine.
The fruity, perfumed character shows instant red berry aromas, but the old-wood flavor doesn't quite chime with the fruit, giving a slightly muddled feel to the wine.
Mint aromas speak of the wood used in aging this wine. With some burnt tannin character, it's perhaps not a wine that will show great fruit.
Earthy aromas are an off-putting start to this heavily tannic wine. It tastes bitter and extracted, the fruit worked too hard during fermentation.
Very dry and hard, with lean black currant fruits. This is likely to remain a tough and extracted wine.
This wine has an unusual candy-flavored character. Its tannins are fine, and there is structure, but the final character is unbalanced.
A firm and tannic wine, with a hard-edge feel to it. The structure is dry and tough, leaving little room for the fruit, even in the future.
High acidity cuts through this wine from the get-go. The tannins also show a hard edge. This is a wine for the future, always with a sense of austerity and minerality.
Almost too fruity, the wine has red berry fruits in profusion. What is missing is the tannin to hold it together, making this a fruity wine to drink soon.
This is a wine for short-term aging. It is rich and juicy, deliciously fruity right now. Give it 2-3 years to enjoy its black fruits and fresh acidity.
This wine has a smoky character and a subtle touch of wood, along with firm tannins and red fruits. Age this for 1-2 years.

This is an attractively perfumed wine, which is polished by the wood influence, offering flavors of mint and eucalyptus. It is rich and spicy, with the weight of black fruits. This is already drinkable, so consume it now, or keep it for 3-4 years.

While this wine has the richness and warmth of its vintage, it also has a fine, dusty, tannic structure, which gives it a serious aspect. Ripe black-plum and berry flavors provide a generous feel, while the crisp acidity offsets the ripeness.

This black-fruited effort is laced with a spicy wood note. It's surprisingly delicious now, considering the firm tannins that compose its core, but the wine also promises some aging. Drink now for fruit, and age for more complexity.
New wood, mint and eucalyptus aromas lead to a palate that is dominated by wood. With the rich fruit underneath, the wine will come into balance, becoming warm and generous, typical of the vintage.

For such a young wine, this is surprisingly mature. Its tannins have softened and rounded, becoming well integrated with the black currant flavor and bright acidity. It's an attractive choice to drink now or over the next few years, but not for long-term aging.

Firm, tannic and dominated by dense black fruits, this has a serious layer of wood that shows through in a smoky, burnt character which needs time to soften. Solid, foursquare and showing the great ripeness of Merlot in 2009.

This is a concentrated wine that is structured and packed with red fruits and solid tannins. It feels weighty and rich; the juicy character is balanced by a firm, dry texture. For aging over several years.

Very structured wine that shows its wood aging as well as textured black plum fruits. It has spice, toast and a smoky character. Underneath are blackberry fruits and a strong layer of acidity. Age for 3-4 years.

Elegant, rich and fruity, with just the right amount of tannic structure. The wine has black currant, sweet acidity and a dense and concentrated texture. While it is rich, it also has a good long, elegant aftertaste.
Rich, wood-aged wine, smooth and ripely fruity. Aromas of mint lead to the polished, ripe, elegant fruit, the tannins surrounded by a comfortable fruit texture. It will age over 4-5 years.
Big, structured tannins lie over the ripe fruit. The wine has a dense character, the young tannins dominant. Given a year, the fine fruit will come through to give a sweeter blackberry character.
Full of rich smoke and black currant fruits, there is already weight here as well as a juicy character. The immediately attractive wine has wood, spice and delicious red fruit acidity to finish.
Initially dominated by wood, then the ripe jammy fruit comes through to give a soft, rich wine, with bitter chocolate as well as red fruit flavors.

This is part of a range of wines from the Bantegnies family's estate. It is ripe and juicy with red fruits and spicy tannins. Wood aging gives some extra depth. Ripe fruit, generous tannins and aging potential all point to a wine with a good future. Drink from 2021.

From an estate that dates to the 16th century, this wine is a ripe, structured example of this great vintage. It has layers of tannins as well as exemplary black-currant fruits. The acidity and structure are right there, giving a wine with excellent potential. Drink from 2021.

Produced by the team that makes Château Haut-Selves in the Graves, this wine is elegant, with a light touch of tannins and acidity. The wine offers spice from barrel aging as well as poised black fruit and acidity. Drink from 2021.

This wine is structured and firm. Its tannins and solid texture promise both aging and show the potential of this rich wine. With intense youthful acidity at this stage, the wine's fruit is crisp and clear. This is one of three Cuvées from Bel Ormeau. Drink this wine from 2022.

This wine from a 14-acre family estate is ripe, soft and full of blackberries. It has a succulent character along with its fruit and acidity. Soft tannins and a ripe texture indicate this wine will develop quickly. Drink from 2019.
This is one of three Cuvées from Bel Ormeau. It is full of red-berry fruits and gentle tannins. Balanced and rounded, it is already generous and certainly ripe. Drink from 2021.
This wine is lean, with a light texture that brings out juicy black fruit and intense acidity. It misses out on the concentration and richness of the vintage.

This wine is a selection from three parcels fermented and aged in barrel. Despite this generous use of wood, the wine is just as much about the bright, ripe fruit of the vintage. Spice, black-currant flavor and concentration give a wine that deserves to age. Drink from 2020.

This wine is full of all the right elements, from juicy acidity to black currant fruit and a supporting layer of tannins. It has weight, concentration and delicious spice and berry flavors. Drink from 2020.
New wood aromas set the scene for this ripe, fuity and toasty wine. It has plenty of black plum fruit, rich tannins and a dry core that will soften. The texture is polished and ripe. Drink from 2020.
This wine is ripe and juicy, with delicious damson and berry fruit. Being rich and full bodied, it's also densely textured, with smoky touches of wood from barrel aging. Drink from 2020.

This wine is rich, spicy and full of black fruit. With solid tannins alongside its juicy black currant flavors, it's firm and will age well. Its density and richness are developing and will be best from 2020.
Although full of fruit, this no-sulfur-added wine is structured and concentrated. Big tannins back up the ripe character and generous fruit flavors. It's likely to be ready to drink from 2021.

This bold, ripe wine is full of tannins as well as great fruit. Juicy with black currant flavors, smoky from wood aging and rich with tannins, it's finely structured and ready to mature gently. Drink from 2021.

This ripe, juicy wine is already attractive and perfumed. Its tannins and wood-aging flavors give weight to its fruit. Spicy and full of black cherry and berry flavors, it's bold and will be ready to drink from 2019.

Initially firmly tannic, this opens to reveal fine blackberry fruit and fresh acidity. It's a generous wine, the wood aging giving tannins and spice while the delicious fruit offers a rounder, smoother side. Drink from 2020.
This juicy, fruity wine has a great backup of tannins. It has a smoky character, along with black currant fruit, lending an attractive balance. That fruit that will develop well. Drink from 2020.

There's a great balance of tannin and fruit in this wine. It has concentration and a bold structure that contrast with the black currant fruit and final acidity. It will develop slowly and well. Drink from 2021.

Mint aromas from new oak aging and spice and toast notes on the palate are part of this young, firm-structured wine. It 's powerful and dense, with great black fruit and acidity. A dry core of tannins indicates it will age. Drink from 2020.
Concentrated and smoky, this wine has plenty of black cherry and black currant fruit. Its firm tannins promise that aging that will make it a richly endowed wine. Drink from 2020.
This wine is juicy and fruity, with generous tannins that support its ripe black fruit and balanced acidity. It has a smoky edge and will be ready to drink from 2020.
This is a fruity, juicy wine with swathes of black currant and berry flavors. The tannins give a smoky, spicy character and add to the sense of richness. Drink from 2020.

Wood aging gives this wine's aroma its eucalyptus character. That perfume follows through to the finely structured palate, where oak flavors balance its delicious black plum fruit. It's warm, ripe and stylish. Drink from 2020.

Generous tannins and blackberry fruit, along with a smooth texture all contribute to the richness of this broad, ripe wine. The 79% Merlot in the blend lends a generous character and the likelihood it will age quickly. Drink from 2018.
Ripe fruit, juicy acidity and a fine balance of tannins give this wine great potential. It's full of blackberry flavors as well as some solid, structured tannins. Drink from 2020.
Smoky wood flavors dominate this dense, wood-aged wine. It also has juicy red berry flavors and will be generous and very fine when mature. Drink from 2020.
Big on tannins and equally big on ripe fruit, this is a rich wine. Its dense texture and bold blackberry flavors are coming together well. Drink from 2021.

Wood spice aromas are an indication this wine that has had serious oak aging. Along with the dense tannins and wood, there is, happily, some fruit that will develop as the structure softens. Drink this powerful wine with its rich berry fruit from 2021.
This dense, tannic wine has spice and black fruit aromas that follow through on the palate, with new wood and black plum flavors. Concentrated and firm, it has fine potential. Drink from 2019.

Eucalyptus aromas add to the ripe fruit in this wine to give both structure and fine potential. With its black plum flavors, rich texture and warm character, it's impressive and ready to age. Drink from 2020.
This perfumed wine is ripe with exuberant black fruit and hints of wood aging. It's juicy with spice and pepper notes as well as bold red fruit. Drink from 2020.
This wine is firm, with dry, smoky tannins that underscore its rich black fruit, promising good aging potential. It will develop slowly and be ready to drink from 2021.

This structured wine is firm with tannins and stalky black currant fruit. It's dry, with a bitter edge from high extraction. A smoky character indicates aggressive wood aging and the need to soften further. Drink from 2020.
This smoky wine is full of wood and spice notes. Ripe fruit is also there, with some solid tannins to back it up. It will develop well. Drink from 2020.

A toasty, spicy aroma reveals the wood-aging flavors that are still firmly in place in this wine. Underneath, there is fine, juicy black currant fruit, crisp acidity and good potential. Drink from 2019.

This solid and dense wine is full of tannins as well as layers of wood and blackberry fruit. It has the potential to gain in richness as it develops. A smoky quality accents its black plum flavors. Drink from 2019.
This ripe and spicy wine has fine tannins and smoky wood flavors that balance its rich black fruit. That indicates it will age well-rich in both structure and fruit. Drink from 2020.

Dark and firm on the one hand, this wine is also full of fruit. Blackberry flavors dominate, but tannins lend support with concentration and density. They just need time to come together. Drink from 2020.

From a Château that has vineyards in both Blaye and Bourg, this wine is redolent of black currant, both on the nose and on the palate. The wood and tannins lend support, giving plenty of space for the ripe fruitiness and juicy acidity. Drink from 2020.
Juicy and rich, this is already developing quickly. Its blackberry fruit is supported by generous tannins, and its dry core offers smoky flavors. Drink this attractive wine from 2019.

This wine's red berry and mint aromas lead to a palate structurd with firm tannins and loaded with juicy fruits. Blackberry and black currant flavors give it great fruitiness. As it develops, they will integrate well. Drink from 2019.

This perfumed wine is firm with tannins that gives a spicy character. It has a dry core, a juicy aftertaste and rich blackberry fruit that will certainly develop as it matures. Give it some time and drink from 2021.
This wine is soft and ripe, with juicy black fruit and fresh acidity over a background of firm tannins. A smoky edge adds to its attractiveness.
Big, bold and spicy, this wine is ripe with black fruit. Tannins and a rich texture confirm its upfront style. Likely to take its time to develop, it will be ready to drink from 2020.
Smooth with polished new wood flavors and fine black fruit, this wine has good potential. Subtle tannins back up its black currant and berry fruit. Drink from 2020.
This finely structured wine is ripe and full of blackberry flavors, with a soft, rich texture. That suggests it will age relatively quickly and be ready to drink from 2019.

This is a powerful wood-aged wine. Spice and toast aromas give it a firm character that will need to soften. Its black plum and berry fruit is upfront, with a juicy element that will fill out. Drink from 2020.
Ripe and fruity, with delicious red berry flavors, this is an attractive wine now. It also has some firm tannins that will allow it to age. Drink from 2019.
This wine is firm, dense and packed with tannins. Juicy acidity lends a crisp character to its dominant black currant fruit. It will take time to soften, so drink from 2020.
Red berry aromas signal an attractive wine that is fragrant and fruity yet has enough tannins to age. Drink from 2019.

Juicy with fine berry fruit, this is an open wine that will develop quickly. With its attractive acidity and smoky character from wood aging, it has the potential to be a delicious wine. Drink from 2020.

Blackberry jam aromas in this wine are followed by a lean palate and ample tannins. It's tough at this stage, but as it opens, the fruit will come through to give damson jelly flavors. Drink from 2020.

This ripe young wine, with its blueberry aroma and spicy palate, is dense and concentrated. It shows the richness of the vintage yet also offers juicy acidity to balance its black plum fruit. Drink from 2019.

Ripe berry aromas set the scene for this balanced, juicy wine. Full of black currant and berry flavors, it's already delicious with its fruitiness. The tannins, though, need to calm down somewhat, and the wine will be better from 2019.
Great black fruit aromas and a perfumed palate give this fruity wine a fine start. It has some firm tannins as well as juicy black currant fruit. Drink from 2019.
This wine is ripe, juicy and full of attractive red berry flavors. Its acidity is balanced by firm, still-young tannins. It will be ready to drink from 2020.
Ripe and fruity, with delicious red berry flavors, this wine is attractive now. It also has some firm tannins built for aging, giving structure to the juicy fruit. Drink from 2019.
Ripe, fruity and dense, this wine has weight and richness. Concentrated with solid tannins, it has smoky flavors and ripe blackberry fruit. Give it until 2020 before drinking.
This jammy wine has plenty of tannins, although they're already fully integrated with the ripe red fruit. Fruity, perfumed and spicy, it finishes with fine acidity. Drink from 2019.

This wine is aromatic, spicy and likely to develop quickly. That shows in the fragrant black currant fruit and generous tannins. Its acidity should be fully integrated with the fruit and the wine ready to drink from 2019.
This wine is firm with powerful surface tannins. Underneath, its blackberry-like fruit is developing, bringing out spice, acidity and plenty of weight. Drink from 2020.
A spearmint aroma give this wine a fresh character. That enhances its berry fruit, spice and perfumed acidity. Drink from 2020.
This Merlot-dominated blend is full of dense fruit, with a soft black currant flavor. A bite of tannin at the back gives structure and aging potential. Drink from 2019.
Smoky, toasty aromas set the scene for a wine that has obviously seen plenty of wood aging. At this stage, it's all spice and wood, which will probably inhibit its development. Wait until 2020.
